metadata.title: The states and effects of copper in Keggin-type heteropolyoxometalate catalysts on oxidation of methacrolein to methacrylic acid

Scheme 1 Mechanism of catalytic performance improved by copper. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 FT-IR spectra of calcined catalysts with different Cu content (Preparation temperature was 30°C, and preparation time was 2h.). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the calcined catalysts with different Cu contents. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of CsPAV, CsCu0.2PAV and CsCu0.5PAV. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 N2 adsorption isotherm line and pore distribution curves of CsPAV and CsCu0.2PAV. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TG-DTA curves of CsPAV and CsCu0.2PAV. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD (left) and H2-TPR (right) curves of the catalysts with different Cu contents. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XPS and Auger spectra of Cu and O 1s in uncalcined, calcined and used catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 MAL conversion and MAA selectivity of the catalysts with different Cu contents at different reaction temperatures. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 MAL conversion and MAA selectivity of catalysts prepared at different temperatures with 2h or with different time at 310°C. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 State of copper cation in the secondary structure of the catalysts. Fig. 10 Table 1 BET surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of the catalysts. Table 1 Catalysts BET surface area/m2 g−1 Pore volume/cm3 g−1 Average pore diameter/nm CsPAV 5.83 0.021 16.40 CsCu0.05PAV 6.80 0.016 7.38 CsCu0.1PAV 5.35 0.017 20.63 CsCu0.2PAV 6.70 0.016 7.6 CsCu0.5PAV 6.32 0.012 11.86 CsCu1PAV 6.80 0.017 7.35 30cCsCu0.2PAV 6.70 0.016 7.6 60cCsCu0.2PAV 6.54 0.014 8.41 80cCsCu0.2PAV 7.12 0.019 8.14 100cCsCu0.2PAV 6.55 0.015 6.70 120cCsCu0.2PAV 5.92 0.010 8.05 2tCsCu0.2PAV 7.12 0.019 8.14 4tCsCu0.2PAV 4.22 0.015 16.3 8tCsCu0.2PAV 4.8 0.020 32.4 12tCsCu0.2PAV 3.06 0.011 31.0 24tCsCu0.2PAV 2.41 0.011 21.6 The states and effects of copper in Keggin-type heteropolyoxometalate catalysts on oxidation of methacrolein to methacrylic acid Lilong Zhou a b Lei Wang a ⁎ Yunli Cao a b Yanyan Diao a Ruiyi Yan a Suojiang Zhang a ⁎ a Beijing Key Laboratory of Ionic Liquids Clean Process, Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Complex Systems, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, PR China Beijing Key Laboratory of Ionic Liquids Clean Process, Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Multiphase Complex Systems, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 PR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Finding out the mechanism how copper improves the catalytic performance is important to design efficient heteropolyoxometalate catalysts for clean production of methacrylic acid. In this work, copper containing heteropolyoxometalate catalysts (CsCu x H3–2x PMo11VO40) were synthesized, characterized and used to catalyze the oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to methacrylic acid. The FT-IR, TG-DTA and XPS results showed that copper was in the forms of Cu2+ and Cu+ and complexes with 4 water molecules in the secondary structure of the catalysts at room temperature. XRD and BET analysis showed that the addition of copper could increase the crystalline size of catalysts, prevent the accumulation of catalyst crystal and make catalysts to be a kind of mesoporous materials with narrow pore width distribution (around 4nm), which is positive for the catalytic performance. The catalytic tests showed that the addition of copper can obviously improve the catalytic performance of catalysts. Copper can get an electron from Keggin structure to improve the oxidation ability of active sites during the oxidation of MAL and give an electron to Keggin structure to make the reduced active sites to be re-oxidized easily. This paper gives a clear picture of copper states in the heteropolyoxometalate catalysts and the mechanism how copper improves the performance of heteropolyoxometalate catalysts s for oxidation reactions. Keywords Methacrolein Methacrylic acid Selective oxidation Copper Heteropolyoxometalate catalysts 1 Introduction As an important kind of catalysts, heteropolyoxometalate catalysts can be used in oxidation, acidic and shape-selective reactions [1–7]. Methacrylic acid (MAA) is an important chemical intermediate which can be used for synthesis of functional polymers, such as polyesters, adhesives and synthetic rubber. Oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to methacrylic acid (MAA) is a green way to produce MAA and a key step for methyl methacrylate clean production, which was usually catalyzed by molybdophosphoric or molybdovanadophosphoric compounds [8–11]. Compared with molybdophosphoric acid, molybdovanadophosphoric acid shows better catalytic performance for the oxidation of MAL to MAA due to the addition of vanadium species. The effects and changes of vanadium species on this oxidation reaction have been investigated in our previous research [11]. Although molybdovanadophosphoric acid is a good catalyst for this reaction, its thermal stability is poor during the reactions [12]. An efficient way to solve this problem is to add Cs+ to the catalysts as the counter ions. The addition of Cs+ also can adjust the acidity, increase the surface area and improve catalytic performance of catalysts [13–15]. However, it is still not good enough for industry application due to its low catalytic efficiency. Some other counter ions, such as Cu2+, Fe3+, NH4 +, were added to further improve the catalytic activity. These counter ions have significant influence on the properties of the catalysts, such as acidity, oxidation ability, surface area and thermal stability [16]. Among these counter ions, Cu2+ shows the best performance for the catalytic activity improvement, which made it the main constituent in many catalysts [10,17–19]. So it is important to find out the states of copper in the catalysts and its role in the oxidation of MAL to MAA. Renaud Bayer et al. added copper into H3PMo12O40 as the counter ions for oxidation of isobutyric acid, and results showed that copper could obviously increase the conversion of isobutyric acid with no influence on MAA selectivity due to its acceleration of the reduced catalysts re-oxidation. Copper in this catalyst was in form of Cu(H2O)4 2+. However, too much copper addition could lead to the decomposition of catalysts [19]. Albonetti S. et al. found that acidity is also increased with the increase of Cu content up to 0.2 per heteropoly anion [20]. Reduction study by Langpape M. et al. showed that copper can act as catalysts and transfer one electron from reactants to neighbor molybdenum cations to accelerate catalysts’ reduction [21]. To the best of our knowledge, few researches focused on the states and effects of copper in heteropolyoxometalate catalysts on the oxidation of MAL to MAA, and the real states and effects of copper on this reaction remains unclear. In this paper, H3−x CsCu x PMo11VO40 (x is the average mole amount of copper per mole heteropolyoxometalate molecule) was prepared and used as the catalyst for the oxidation of MAL to MAA. The sates of this series of catalysts before and after calcination and reaction were studied by different methods, such as FT-IR, Raman, XRD, BET, SEM, UV-vis, XPS, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR, and the effects on the reaction were also investigated. This research has revealed the influence of copper on different aspects of catalysts. 2 Experiments 2.1 Preparation of catalysts H4PMo11VO40 (HPAV) was prepared from MoO3 (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), V2O5 (Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute) and 85% phosphoric acid (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) according to the reported procedures [22]. 5g MoO3 and 0.287g V2O5 were added to 100mL deionized water, which was subsequently heated to reflux. Moreover, 0.364g of 85% phosphoric acid was added to the mixture, which was refluxed with vigorous stirring for 5h. A deep-orange solution was formed. The insoluble solid was filtered, and the solution was evaporated at 80°C, and bright orange powder was finally obtained. Copper doped catalysts were prepared by the following procedure. Firstly, 5g HPAV was dissolved in 20mL deionized water, and then 10mL solution with 0.547g CsNO3 and Cu(NO3)2·H2O was dripped into the HPAV solution. The suspension was stirred and heated for several hours. The suspension was evaporated at 80°C to get the solid catalysts, and the catalysts were dried in oven at 80°C for 12h. All catalysts were calcined at 360°C under a flow of air at a flow rate of 80mL/min. The catalysts were named as x c °rtCsCu n PAV, where x c is preparation temperature and x t is preparation time, and n is Cu mole content in per mole catalyst molecules. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected by an FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet 380, Thermal Electron Corporation) with anhydrous KBr as standard. The surface area and pore structure of the catalysts were analyzed by Surface area and Pore Analyzer (Mocromeritics ASAP 2460, US). The oxidation and acid properties of the catalysts were tested by hydrogen temperature programmed reduction and ammonia temperature programmed desorption on AutoChemIIChemisorption Analyzer (Micromeritics). The microcosmic pattern of the catalysts was observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM, SU8020, Hitachi Electronic Electric Appliance Company, Japan). Samples (about 25mg) were also analyzed by conducting thermogravimetry/differential thermal analysis (DTG-60H, Shimadzu, Japan) using a simultaneous DTA-TG apparatus, which allowed both TGA and DSC curves to be recorded simultaneously. The samples were heated from room temperature to 600°C at a heating rate of 5°Cmin−1. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) diffuse reflectance spectroscopy was recorded using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (UV-2550, Shimadzu Corporation). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance X-ray Powder Diffractometer). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded using a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer with monochromatic Al Kα radiation. 2.3 Catalysts test Catalytic oxidation of MAL to MAA was performed under atmosphere pressure. Catalysts were pressed into a piece at 8MPa. The piece was then smashed and sieved into particles of 20–40 meshes. 0.8mL catalyst was loaded in a fix bed reactor (the reactor was 400mm long with an internal diameter of 6mm.). The contact time was about 2s. Temperature was increased to given reaction temperature at first, then reactants mixtures of MAL (4.4vol.%), O2 (11.1vol.%), H2O (17.8vol.%) and N2 (balance) were fed into the reactor to start the reactions. After the reactions went steady, the products were collected and analyzed by GC (7890B, Agilent Technologies Co. Ltd) which was equipped by a flame ionization detector and a capillary column (DB-FFAP). Every catalyst was tested at least for 3 times at different temperatures. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 FT-IR As shown in Fig. 1 , the four characteristic vibration bands of Keggin structure appear at 1063, 963, 870 and 775cm−1 in the FT-IR spectra of CsPAV, which can be assigned to vs (P–O), vs(Mo=Od), vs (Mo–Ob–Mo) and vs (Mo–Oc–Mo) bands, respectively [10]. The band at 1036cm−1 can be assigned to V–O vibration band, which was formed by the migration of V from primary structure to the secondary structure of the catalysts [10]. The band at 591cm−1 can be ascribed to vs (Mo–O) in MoO3 [11], indicating that CsPAV was partially decomposed during preparation and calcination. The band around 3450cm−1 can be assigned to the vibration of O–H in crystalline water [23]. It suggests that some crystalline water existed in the catalysts. If the copper cation directly contacted with Keggin structure, the wavenumber of vs (Mo=Od) and vs (Mo–Ob–Mo) would be changed with the addition of copper. In fact, no changes were detected by FT-IR with the addition of copper. A weak band emerged at 505cm−1 where the characteristic band of CuO appeared, suggesting that copper ions was in similar form with CuO (Figs. S1 and S2) [24]. In order to balance electric charge, copper should be in ion forms. So this band should be caused by the complex of copper ions with O in water molecules. Compared with the spectra of CsPAV, vs (Mo–Oc–Mo) band shifted to high wavenumber (blue shift) with the increase of copper content up to 0.5 per heteropoly anion (Table S1). The blue shift of this band indicates that electrons in Keggin structure were attracted by Cu in the secondary structure. The blue shift also suggests that the oxidation state of Mo in the catalysts became stronger with the addition of copper. The V–O band was very weak in the spectra of CsCu x PAV. After being used in reaction, the V–O band became more obvious in the spectra of CsCu x PAV than it in the spectrum of the catalyst before evaluation (Fig. S4). It suggests that V continued to migrate from Keggin structure to the secondary structure to form active VO2+ during reaction. No obvious differences were found in the spectra of the catalysts prepared at different temperature and with different preparation time (Figs. S6 ad S7), implying preparation temperature and time have little influence on the primary structure of catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1 , the four characteristic vibration bands of Keggin structure appear at 1063, 963, 870 and 775cm−1 in the FT-IR spectra of CsPAV, which can be assigned to vs (P–O), vs(Mo=Od), vs (Mo–Ob–Mo) and vs (Mo–Oc–Mo) bands, respectively [10]. The band at 1036cm−1 can be assigned to V–O vibration band, which was formed by the migration of V from primary structure to the secondary structure of the catalysts [10]. The band at 591cm−1 can be ascribed to vs (Mo–O) in MoO3 [11], indicating that CsPAV was partially decomposed during preparation and calcination. The band around 3450cm−1 can be assigned to the vibration of O–H in crystalline water [23]. It suggests that some crystalline water existed in the catalysts. If the copper cation directly contacted with Keggin structure, the wavenumber of vs (Mo=Od) and vs (Mo–Ob–Mo) would be changed with the addition of copper. In fact, no changes were detected by FT-IR with the addition of copper. A weak band emerged at 505cm−1 where the characteristic band of CuO appeared, suggesting that copper ions was in similar form with CuO (Figs. S1 and S2) [24]. In order to balance electric charge, copper should be in ion forms. So this band should be caused by the complex of copper ions with O in water molecules. Compared with the spectra of CsPAV, vs (Mo–Oc–Mo) band shifted to high wavenumber (blue shift) with the increase of copper content up to 0.5 per heteropoly anion (Table S1). The blue shift of this band indicates that electrons in Keggin structure were attracted by Cu in the secondary structure. The blue shift also suggests that the oxidation state of Mo in the catalysts became stronger with the addition of copper. The V–O band was very weak in the spectra of CsCu x PAV. After being used in reaction, the V–O band became more obvious in the spectra of CsCu x PAV than it in the spectrum of the catalyst before evaluation (Fig. S4). It suggests that V continued to migrate from Keggin structure to the secondary structure to form active VO2+ during reaction. No obvious differences were found in the spectra of the catalysts prepared at different temperature and with different preparation time (Figs. S6 and S7), implying preparation temperature and time have little influence on the primary structure of catalysts. 3.1.2 XRD As can be seen in Fig. 2 , the XRD patterns of CsPAV showed that it's in cubic form as previously reported [13], and no other chemicals were detected. In the patterns of CsCu x PAV, other peaks (8.0°, 8.8°, 9.2°, 17.8°, 18.5°, 20.1°, 20.4°, 26.7°, 27.8°, 28.4°, 29°) belonging to cubic form of HPAV were appeared besides the patterns of CsPAV, suggesting that the addition of copper may restrict the reaction between Cs+ and PMo11VO40 4+. So the addition of copper may influence the crystallization of catalysts. With the increase of copper content, the peaks belong to HPAV became weaker and weaker due to the substitution of protons in the catalysts by the copper cation. No CuO were detected by XRD. It further proved that copper was not in form of CuO in catalysts. With the increase of preparation temperature and time, the peaks of HPAV disappeared (Figs. S8 and S9), indicating that the increase of temperature and the extension of reaction time can improve the re-crystallization of the catalysts and make PMo11VO40 4− react completely with Cs+. The crystalline diameters of the catalysts were calculated by Scherrer formula, D hkl = kλ/βcosθ hkl , where k is shape factor, for cubic the value is 0.9; λ is the wavelength of X-ray (nm); β is FWHM (radian); θ hkl is diffraction angle (radian). As can be seen in Table S2, the crystalline diameter of CsCu x PAV was much lager than that of CsPAV, suggesting that the addition of copper can enlarge the crystalline diameter of catalysts. Compared with the particle sizes calculated by BET surface area and density, the sizes calculated by BET data showed the similar trend as those calculated by XRD data (crystal size of catalysts) that the catalysts with small surface area were in large particle sizes. Because of the existence of inner pores in catalysts particles and the cluster of crystals, so the particles sizes calculated by BET data were much larger than those calculated by XRD data (Table S2). To further study the influence of copper on the physical properties of the catalysts, SEM and BET were performed. As can be seen in Fig. 2 , the XRD patterns of CsPAV showed that it's in cubic form as previously reported [13], and no other chemicals were detected. In the patterns of CsCu x PAV, other peaks (8.0°, 8.8°, 9.2°, 17.8°, 18.5°, 20.1°, 20.4°, 26.7°, 27.8°, 28.4°, 29°) belonging to cubic form of HPAV were appeared besides the patterns of CsPAV, suggesting that the addition of copper may restrict the reaction between Cs+ and PMo11VO40 4+. So the addition of copper may influence the crystallization of catalysts. With the increase of copper content, the peaks belong to HPAV became weaker and weaker due to the substitution of protons in the catalysts by the copper cation. No CuO were detected by XRD. It further proved that copper was not in form of CuO in catalysts. With the increase of preparation temperature and time, the peaks of HPAV disappeared (Figs. S8 and S9), indicating that the increase of temperature and the extension of reaction time can improve the re-crystallization of the catalysts and make PMo11VO40 4− react completely with Cs+. The crystalline diameters of the catalysts were calculated by Scherrer formula, D hkl = kλ/βcosθ hkl , where k is shape factor, for cubic the value is 0.9; λ is the wavelength of X-ray (nm); β is FWHM (radian); θ hkl is diffraction angle (radian). As can be seen in Table S2, the crystalline diameter of CsCu x PAV was much lager than that of CsPAV, suggesting that the addition of copper can enlarge the crystalline diameter of catalysts. Compared with the particle sizes calculated by BET surface area and density, the sizes calculated by BET data showed the similar trend as those calculated by XRD data (crystal size of catalysts) that the catalysts with small surface area were in large particle sizes. Because of the existence of inner pores in catalysts particles and the cluster of crystals, so the particles sizes calculated by BET data were much larger than those calculated by XRD data (Table S2). To further study the influence of copper on the physical properties of the catalysts, SEM and BET were performed. 3.1.3 SEM In Fig. 3 , we can see that CsPAV was particles without particular shapes. The small particles clustered to form large blocks. With the addition of copper, some interesting changes occurred (Fig. 3 and Figs. S12–S15). Firstly, catalysts crystallized in spheres with size of 50–100nm, which were much smaller than the blocks of CsPAV. According to the calculated results from XRD data, these spheres should compose one or two catalyst crystals. So the addition of copper can prevent the cluster of catalyst crystals, and more active sites will expose to the feed. Secondly, some holes can be found on these spheres (Fig. S15), indicating that some of these spheres might be hollow. It's difficult to distinguish the differences of the images between catalysts with different copper content. While, the differences between catalysts prepared at different temperature or with different time were more obvious (Figs. S13 and S14). The spheres of the catalysts prepared at high temperature and with long preparation time were smoother than the ones prepared at low temperature or with short preparation time due to the re-crystallization of catalysts, respectively. In Fig. 3 , we can see that CsPAV was particles without particular shapes. The small particles clustered to form large blocks. With the addition of copper, some interesting changes occurred (Fig. 3 and Figs. S12–S15). Firstly, catalysts crystallized in spheres with size of 50–100nm, which were much smaller than the blocks of CsPAV. According to the calculated results from XRD data, these spheres should compose one or two catalyst crystals. So the addition of copper can prevent the cluster of catalyst crystals, and more active sites will expose to the feed. Secondly, some holes can be found on these spheres (Fig. S15), indicating that some of these spheres might be hollow. It's difficult to distinguish the differences of the images between catalysts with different copper content. While, the differences between catalysts prepared at different temperature or with different time were more obvious (Figs. S13 and S14). The spheres of the catalysts prepared at high temperature and with long preparation time were smoother than the ones prepared at low temperature or with short preparation time due to the re-crystallization of catalysts, respectively. 3.1.4 BET BET was performed to find out influence of copper on the surface area and pore structure of catalysts. Both the N2 absorption isotherm line and the pore distribution curve of CsPAV showed that the pores in this catalyst were slit pore (Fig. 4 ). The surface area of CsPAV was about 6m2 g−1 (Table 1 ). As can be seen in Fig. 4 and Fig. S14, the addition of copper obviously changed the pore structure of the catalysts. The pore distribution curves suggest that pores in unitary size were formed by the addition of copper, while the surface area little changed (Table 1). With the increase of preparation temperature, the surface area of catalysts had little changed, while the pore volume increased up to 0.0021cm3 g−1 and then decreased to 0.0017cm3 g−1 due to the acceleration of re-crystallization process of the catalysts. The average pore diameters changed obviously by the addition of copper and changing of preparation conditions. As can be seen in Fig. 4 and Figs. S14–S16, the pore diameters in CsPAV widely distributed. These pores were slit pores formed from the accumulation of CsPAV particles. So its pore diameter distribution is wide and average pore diameter is lager. With the addition of copper, a kind of pores with narrow pore diameter (about 4nm) was formed. With the increase of preparation temperature and time, catalysts further re-crystallized, and pores in catalysts also changed. So the average pore diameters of catalysts prepared in different conditions were different. BET was performed to find out influence of copper on the surface area and pore structure of catalysts. Both the N2 absorption isotherm line and the pore distribution curve of CsPAV showed that the pores in this catalyst were slit pore (Fig. 4 ). The surface area of CsPAV was about 6m2 g−1 (Table 1 ). As can be seen in Fig. 4 and Fig. S14, the addition of copper obviously changed the pore structure of the catalysts. The pore distribution curves suggest that pores in unitary size were formed by the addition of copper, while the surface area little changed (Table 1). With the increase of preparation temperature, the surface area of catalysts had little changed, while the pore volume increased up to 0.0021cm3 g−1 and then decreased to 0.0017cm3 g−1 due to the acceleration of re-crystallization process of the catalysts. The average pore diameters changed obviously by the addition of copper and changing of preparation conditions. As can be seen in Fig. 4 and Figs. S14–S16, the pore diameters in CsPAV widely distributed. These pores were slit pores formed from the accumulation of CsPAV particles. So its pore diameter distribution is wide and average pore diameter is lager. With the addition of copper, a kind of pores with narrow pore diameter (about 4nm) was formed. With the increase of preparation temperature and time, catalysts further re-crystallized, and pores in catalysts also changed. So the average pore diameters of catalysts prepared in different conditions were different. 3.1.5 TG-DTA As can be seen in Fig. 5 , three weight losing steps can be found in the TG curves of these two catalysts. These three steps can be assigned to the lost of crystalline water (30–170°C), decomposition of NO3 − (170–300°C) in the catalysts and decomposition of the catalysts (300–450°C) in which P was lost in the form of P2O5, respectively [10]. There were two radiative peaks in the DTA curves of both catalysts. The first one emerging at 320°C can be ascribed to the onset decomposition of catalysts, and the second one (450°C) was caused by the total decomposition of the catalysts. The amount of water in both catalysts was calculated by the weight loss. There were six water molecules per Keggin structure in CsPAV and eight per Keggin structure in CsCu0.2PAV. The two more water molecules in CsCu0.2PAV should be complex water with copper. Ten water molecules per heteropoly anion can be detected by TG-DTA in CsCu1PAV (Fig. S20). In CsCu0.2PAV, only 20% heteropoly anions could contact with copper cation, so four water molecules were complex with copper cation in the secondary structure of catalysts. After calcination, four water molecules per Keggin structure were left in CsCu0.2PAV (Fig. S19). These removed water molecules should include the ones complex with the copper cation. As can be seen in Fig. 5 , three weight losing steps can be found in the TG curves of these two catalysts. These three steps can be assigned to the lost of crystalline water (30–170°C), decomposition of NO3 − (170–300°C) in the catalysts and decomposition of the catalysts (300–450°C) in which P was lost in the form of P2O5, respectively [10]. There were two radiative peaks in the DTA curves of both catalysts. The first one emerging at 320°C can be ascribed to the onset decomposition of catalysts, and the second one (450°C) was caused by the total decomposition of the catalysts. The amount of water in both catalysts was calculated by the weight loss. There were six water molecules per Keggin structure in CsPAV and eight per Keggin structure in CsCu0.2PAV. The two more water molecules in CsCu0.2PAV should be complex water with copper. Ten water molecules per heteropoly anion can be detected by TG-DTA in CsCu1PAV (Fig. S20). In CsCu0.2PAV, only 20% heteropoly anions could contact with copper cation, so four water molecules were complex with copper cation in the secondary structure of catalysts. After calcination, four water molecules per Keggin structure were left in CsCu0.2PAV (Fig. S19). These removed water molecules should include the ones complex with the copper cation. 3.1.6 NH3-TPD and H2-TPR Acidity and oxidation ability are the main properties influencing the catalytic performance of catalysts. So the influence of copper on these properties was determined by NH3-TPD and H2-TPR, and the results were shown in Fig. 6 . Two peaks can be found in the NH3-TPD curve of CsPAV. The one between 90 and 150°C can be assigned to weak acid sites. The other one emerged between 350 and 550°C can be related to the strong acid sites which showed the main acidity of the catalysts. A new weak acid site emerged at about 160 (CsCu0.05PAV) or 200°C (other catalysts in Fig. 6) after the addition of copper. The strength and amount of this acid site became stronger with the increase of copper amount. Obviously, it was caused by the addition of copper. With the copper amount increasing to 0.5 per heteropoly anion, a middle strong acid site appeared around 330°C. The addition of copper reduced both the strength and acid amount of the catalysts due to the replacement of protons by copper cations. As can be seen in Fig. 6 (right), only one peak appearing in the H2-TPR profile of CsPAV around 610°C can be assigned to the reduction peak of oxides formed from the decomposition of CsPAV [10]. With the addition of copper, a new peak emerged around 370°C, and the peak belonging to oxides formed from the decomposition of catalysts was also shifted to lower temperature. It suggested a new oxidation site formed. With the increase of copper amount, the new oxidation site became more and more and continued to shift to low temperature [370°C (CsCu0.1PAV), 325°C (CsCu0.2PAV), 320°C (CsCu0.5PAV) and 275°C (CsCu1PAV)]. The oxidation site of CuO emerged at about 180°C, which was different from the one in the catalysts (Fig. S3). It suggests that copper in the catalysts was not in form of CuO, and the addition of copper can obviously enhance the oxidation ability of catalysts, which may be helpful to improve the catalytic performance of the catalysts. As can be seen in Fig. 6 (right), only one peak appearing in the H2-TPR profile of CsPAV around 610°C can be assigned to the reduction peak of oxides formed from the decomposition of CsPAV [10]. With the addition of copper, a new peak emerged around 370°C, and the peak belonging to oxides formed from the decomposition of catalysts was also shifted to lower temperature. It suggested a new oxidation site formed. With the increase of copper amount, the new oxidation site became more and more and continued to shift to low temperature [370°C (CsCu0.1PAV), 325°C (CsCu0.2PAV), 320°C (CsCu0.5PAV) and 275°C (CsCu1PAV)]. The oxidation site of CuO emerged at about 180°C, which was different from the one in the catalysts (Fig. S3). It suggests that copper in the catalysts was not in form of CuO, and the addition of copper can obviously enhance the oxidation ability of catalysts, which may be helpful to improve the catalytic performance of the catalysts. 3.1.7 XPS XPS was performed to find out how copper improve the oxidation ability of catalysts. Elements (Cu, Mo and V) which could change chemical valences during calcination and reaction were investigated. As can be seen in Fig. 7 , the binding energy of Cu 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 in the catalysts was about 933 and 953eV, respectively, which only changed a little after calcination and reaction. Satellite peaks of these two peaks also can be found in the spectra, which suggests that Cu(II) was in the catalysts [25,26]. In Auger electron spectra of uncalcined catalysts, two different peaks emerged at 917.3 and 915eV, which can be assigned to Cu(II) and Cu(I), respectively [27,28]. After calcination, the kinetic energy of both copper species increased a little, and the mole ratio of Cu(II) also obviously increased due to the oxidation of Cu(I) by oxygen in air (Table S3). Mole ratio of Cu(II) obviously decreased after reaction due to the reduction of catalysts by MAL. The kinetic energy of both copper species increased due to the interaction with heteropoly anions becoming stronger. Copper was not active sites, and it was oxidized and reduced by other species in the catalysts. It might act as a media to deliver electrons among active species in different chemical states. XPS was performed to find out how copper improve the oxidation ability of catalysts. Elements (Cu, Mo and V) which could change chemical valences during calcination and reaction were investigated. As can be seen in Fig. 7 , the binding energy of Cu 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 in the catalysts was about 933 and 953eV, respectively, which only changed a little after calcination and reaction. Satellite peaks of these two peaks also can be found in the spectra, which suggests that Cu(II) was in the catalysts [28,29]. In Auger electron spectra of uncalcined catalysts, two different peaks emerged at 917.3 and 915eV, which can be assigned to Cu(II) and Cu(I), respectively [27,28] After calcination, the kinetic energy of both copper species increased a little, and the mole ratio of Cu(II) also obviously increased due to the oxidation of Cu(I) by oxygen in air (Table S3). Mole ratio of Cu(II) obviously decreased after reaction due to the reduction of catalysts by MAL. The kinetic energy of both copper species increased due to the interaction with heteropoly anions becoming stronger. Copper was not active sites, and it was oxidized and reduced by other species in the catalysts. It might act as a media to deliver electrons among active species in different chemical states. Only one peak (233.2eV) belonging to Mo was found in the spectra of uncalcined CsPAV, calcined CsPAV and uncalcined CsCu0.2PAV (Figs. S23 and S24), which can be assigned to Mo(VI) in Keggin structure [11]. After reaction, a new peak at 232.68eV which can be assigned to Mo(V) was detected [29]. Obviously, it was formed from the reduction of Mo(VI) by MAL during reaction. For CsCu x PAV, Mo(V) emerged after calcination. Compared with CsPAV, more Mo(V) was found in CsCu x PAV after reaction (Table S4 1.4% in used CsPAV and 9.3% in CsCu x PAV). It suggests that more Mo atoms in CsCuxPAV participated in reaction than ones in CsPAV, and the copper cation make Mo in the catalysts to be reduced more easily than the one in CsPAV. Two different vanadium species were detected in the catalysts (Figs. S23 and S24). The one emerged around 518eV can be assigned to V(V) in Keggin structure, and the other one around 517eV belongs to V(IV) in VO2+ in the secondary structure of catalysts [11]. The addition of copper had the same influence on V as Mo in the catalysts that the binding energy of both vanadyl species increased. The amount of V(V) and its binding energy were both increased after calcination due to the oxidation of catalysts by oxygen. Before calcination, more V(IV) existed in CsCuxPAV than that in CsPAV. It suggests that the addition of copper is positive to the formation of V(IV). More V(V) existed in CsCuxPAV (79.2%) than it in CsPAV (69.7%) after calcination (Table S5). More V(IV) formed in CsCu x PAV (56.5%) than that in CsPAV (31.3%) after usage. It indicates that the addition of copper cation can enhance the V(IV)–V(V) redox cycle, and the copper cation played the same role for Mo. Only one peak (233.2eV) belonging to Mo was found in the spectra of uncalcined CsPAV, calcined CsPAV and uncalcined CsCu0.2PAV (Figs. S23 and S24), which can be assigned to Mo(VI) in Keggin structure [11]. After reaction, a new peak at 232.68eV which can be assigned to Mo(V) was detected [29]. Obviously, it was formed from the reduction of Mo(VI) by MAL during reaction. For CsCu x PAV, Mo(V) emerged after calcination. Compared with CsPAV, more Mo(V) was found in CsCu x PAV after reaction (Table S4 1.4% in used CsPAV and 9.3% in CsCu x PAV). It suggests that more Mo atoms in CsCuxPAV participated in reaction than ones in CsPAV, and the copper cation make Mo in the catalysts to be reduced more easily than the one in CsPAV. Two different vanadium species were detected in the catalysts (Figs. S23 and S24). The one emerged around 518eV can be assigned to V(V) in Keggin structure, and the other one around 517eV belongs to V(IV) in VO2+ in the secondary structure of catalysts [11]. The addition of copper had the same influence on V as Mo in the catalysts that the binding energy of both vanadyl species increased. The amount of V(V) and its binding energy were both increased after calcination due to the oxidation of catalysts by oxygen. Before calcination, more V(IV) existed in CsCuxPAV than that in CsPAV. It suggests that the addition of copper is positive to the formation of V(IV). More V(V) existed in CsCuxPAV (79.2%) than it in CsPAV (69.7%) after calcination (Table S5). More V(IV) formed in CsCu x PAV (56.5%) than that in CsPAV (31.3%) after usage. It indicates that the addition of copper cation can enhance the V(IV)–V(V) redox cycle, and the copper cation played the same role for Mo. 4 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the catalysts with various copper contents for the oxidation of MAL to MAA was evaluated, and the results are shown in Figs. 8 and 9 , respectively. The preparation temperature and time were also evaluated. As can be seen in Fig. 9, with the increase of reaction temperature, the MAL conversion on all catalysts increased, and the MAA selectivity increased at first and then decreased. With the reaction temperature increased from 290°C to 350°C, MAL conversion on CsPAV, CsCu0.05PAV, CsCu0.1PAV, CsCu0.2PAV, CsCu0.5PAV and CsCu1PAV increased from 4%, 8.7%, 23.5%, 24.1%, 24.2% and 23.2% to 40.1%, 60.7%, 84.1%, 86.2%, 94.9% and 98%, respectively. With the increase of copper amount to 1 per heteropoly anion, MAL conversion increased from 28.7% to 85% at 310°C. CsCu1PAV showed the highest MAL conversion. The addition of copper also increased the MAA selectivity significantly. The selectivity increased from 46.9% (CsPAV) to 97.9% (CsCu0.2PAV) and then decreased to 75.6% (CsCu1PAV) at 310°C. Considering the catalytic activity and selectivity, the following studies of preparation conditions was performed on CsCu0.2PAV. MAL conversion did not change too much, fluctuating around 65% with the increase of preparation temperature, while the selectivity increased from 86.8% (30cCsCu0.2PAV) to 98% (80cCsCu0.2PAV), and then decreased a little (Fig. 10 , left) with preparation temperature of catalyst varying from 30°C to 120°C. Selectivity reached the maximum when preparation temperature was 80°C. The catalysts prepared with different time were prepared at 80°C. With the preparation time extending, the MAL conversion also fluctuating around 65%, and the selectivity decreased from 86.8% to 84%. So the extension of preparation time is negative for the catalytic performance. According to the characterization and catalytic results, copper entered into the secondary structure and complexed with water molecules during preparation (Fig. 10). Copper influences the physical and chemical properties of catalysts and improves the catalytic performance significantly. Apparently, the addition of copper influenced the crystallization of the catalysts, and then influenced the catalytic performance. The crystal sizes of CsCu x PAV were about 20nm, which were larger than that of CsPAV, and some uniform mesoporous pores formed in CsCu x PAV. The crystal of CsPAV was clustered in different sizes and shapes, while the crystal of CsCu x PAV was in the form of hollow sphere and well dispersed. The mesoporous pores were formed during the process of evaporation and calcination, when water molecules in the secondary structure were removed. These uniform pores were in favor of MAL diffusion from feed flux to active species and MAA diffusion from pores in the catalysts to flux. The existence of Cu(H2O)4 2+ also inhibited the aggregation of catalysts crystal, so CsCu x PAV dispersed in single or couple crystal. So more active species exposed to feed which was helpful to improve catalytic performance. According to the mechanism of oxidation of MAL to MAA, MAL was firstly absorbed on the catalysts, then it was oxidized to MAA, and MAA desorbed to the feed flow. The reduced catalysts were re-oxidized by O2 [22]. As analyzed by XPS, copper in the catalysts showed two chemical states, Cu(I) and Cu(II). So only one electron was transferred between a copper cation and Keggin structure. An electron was transferred from Keggin structure to Cu2+, so Cu+ was produced, and the oxidation ability of the active sites was enhanced. After the active sites were reduced by MAL during reaction, the binding energy of Mo and V in CsCu0.2PAV was lower than those in CsPAV, and the amount of these two elements in CsCu0.2PAV was also more than those in CsPAV. It indicates that an electron was given to Keggin structure by Cu+, and Cu+ was oxidized to Cu2+ during reaction. So these active sites were re-oxidized more easily than those in CsPAV. At this point, the copper cation played a role as a media for active sites redox process. During MAL oxidation, Cu2+ drawn an electron from Keggin structure and increased the oxidation ability of the active sites (molybdenum and vanadium species), so MAL was oxidized to MAA more easily than it on CsPAV. Cu+ gave an electron to Keggin structure during re-oxidation process of the catalysts and made the reduced active sites be re-oxidized more easily than those in CsPAV (Scheme 1 ). So the catalytic cycle was accelerated, and less MAA was further oxidized to byproducts, so MAA selectivity was improved. The catalytic activity increased with the increase of reaction temperature, while the MAA selectivity increased firstly and then decreased. With the increase of reaction temperature, more and more MAL molecules with enough energy were oxidized on the catalysts, so the catalytic performance was improved. With the further increase of reaction temperature, MAA was oxidized to byproducts, and its selectivity decreased. The MAL conversion increased with the increase of copper amount, while MAA selectivity increased with the copper amount up to 0.2 per heteropoly anion, and then decreased. As we analyzed in Section 3.1.6, the oxidation ability of catalysts became stronger and stronger with the increase of copper content. However, too strong oxidation ability would accelerate the oxidation process of MAA to byproducts. When the copper amount was up to 0.2 per heteropoly anion, the acceleration rate of side reactions was faster than the target reaction, so MAA selectivity decreased. The preparation temperature and time mainly influence the crystallization process of the catalysts. The crystal sizes of the catalysts increased slightly with the increase of preparation temperature and time (Section 3.1.2). The surface area decreased with the increase of preparation time. These two factors also influenced the chemical properties. The acidity of the catalysts increased with the increase of preparation temperature and time due to the re-crystallization of the catalysts (Fig. S19 and S20). The smooth surface of catalysts was favorable to transfer protons from bulk to the surface. The catalytic activity increased with the preparation temperature up to 80°C, and then decreased with the preparation temperature further increasing due to the changes of acidity, while, the MAA selectivity almost was not influenced. MAL conversion decreased with the extension of preparation time due to the decrease of surface area. The preparation temperature and time mainly influence the crystallization process of the catalysts. The crystal sizes of the catalysts increased slightly with the increase of preparation temperature and time (Section 3.1.2). The surface area decreased with the increase of preparation time. These two factors also influenced the chemical properties. The acidity of the catalysts increased with the increase of preparation temperature and time due to the re-crystallization of the catalysts (Fig. S19 and S20). The smooth surface of catalysts was favorable to transfer protons from bulk to the surface. The catalytic activity increased with the preparation temperature up to 80°C, and then decreased with the preparation temperature further increasing due to the changes of acidity, while, the MAA selectivity almost was not influenced. MAL conversion decreased with the extension of preparation time due to the decrease of surface area. 5 Conclusion In this research, copper containing heteropolyoxometalate catalysts (CsCu x PMo11VO40) were synthesized, characterized and used to catalyze the oxidation of MAL to MAA. Copper is in forms of Cu2+ and Cu+ and complexes with 4 water molecules in the secondary structure of the catalysts at room temperature. The addition of copper can increase the crystal size of the catalysts, prevent the accumulation of catalyst crystal and make the catalysts to be a kind of mesoporous materials with narrow pore width distribution. The addition of copper can obviously improve the catalytic performance of the heteropolyoxometalate catalysts. Copper can get an electron from Keggin anion and improve the oxidation ability of the active sites during the oxidation of MAL and give an electron to Keggin anion and make the reduced active sites re-oxidized easily in the step of re-oxidation of the catalysts. This paper clearly shows the states of copper cation in the secondary structure of heteropolyoxometalate catalysts and mechanism of how copper improves the catalytic performance of heteropolyoxometalate catalysts for selective oxidation reactions. coredata.dc:description: Finding out the mechanism how copper improves the catalytic performance is important to design efficient heteropolyoxometalate catalysts for clean production of methacrylic acid. In this work, copper containing heteropolyoxometalate catalysts (CsCu x H3–2x PMo11VO40) were synthesized, characterized and used to catalyze the oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to methacrylic acid. The FT-IR, TG-DTA and XPS results showed that copper was in the forms of Cu2+ and Cu+ and complexes with 4 water molecules in the secondary structure of the catalysts at room temperature. XRD and BET analysis showed that the addition of copper could increase the crystalline size of catalysts, prevent the accumulation of catalyst crystal and make catalysts to be a kind of mesoporous materials with narrow pore width distribution (around 4nm), which is positive for the catalytic performance. The catalytic tests showed that the addition of copper can obviously improve the catalytic performance of catalysts. Copper can get an electron from Keggin structure to improve the oxidation ability of active sites during the oxidation of MAL and give an electron to Keggin structure to make the reduced active sites to be re-oxidized easily. This paper gives a clear picture of copper states in the heteropolyoxometalate catalysts and the mechanism how copper improves the performance of heteropolyoxometalate catalysts s for oxidation reactions.
coredata.dc:title: The states and effects of copper in Keggin-type heteropolyoxometalate catalysts on oxidation of methacrolein to methacrylic acid
